{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Citizens Business Bank Arena | nickname = | logo_image = [[Image:Citizens Business Bank Arena (logo).png|100px]] | image = [[File:Metallica 2008 Ontario California.jpg|250px]] | address = 4000 East Ontario Center Parkway | location = [[Ontario, California]] | broke_ground = March 7, 2007 | built = | opened = October 18, 2008 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Ontario, California|City of Ontario]] | operator = [[SMG (property management)|SMG]] | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]150 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|150000000|2008}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = [[Rossetti Architects]]{{cite web |title=Citizens Business Bank Arena|url=http://iconvenue.com/portfolio/citizens-business-bank-arena|publisher=ICON Venue Group|date=October 15, 2008|accessdate=November 3, 2011}} | structural engineer = Englekirk Partners Consulting Engineers, Inc. | services engineer = M-E Engineers, Inc. | project_manager = ICON Venue Group | general_contractor = [[Turner Construction]]{{cite web |title=Other Projects Wrapping Up This Year|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2008/01/20080121/SBJ-In-Depth/Other-Projects-Wrapping-Up-This-Year.aspx|work=SportsBusiness Journal|date=January 21, 2008|accessdate=November 3, 2011}} | publictransit = [[San Bernardino Line|{{color box|#{{SCAX color|San Bernardino}}}}]] [[Rancho Cucamonga station|Rancho Cucamonga]] | former_names = Ontario Community Events Center | tenants = ; Arena football [[Los Angeles Temptation]] ([[Legends Football League|LFL]]) (2011–2014; 2016–present)
[[Ontario Warriors]] ([[American Indoor Football|AIF]]) (2012)
[[Las Vegas Sin]] ([[Legends Football League|LFL]]) (2015) ; Basketball [[Los Angeles D-Fenders]] ([[NBA Development League|NBA D-League]]) (2014–2015)
[[Agua Caliente Clippers]] ([[NBA G League]]) (2017–present) ; Ice hockey [[Ontario Reign (ECHL)|Ontario Reign]] ([[ECHL]]) (2008–2015)
[[Ontario Reign (AHL)|Ontario Reign]] ([[American Hockey League|AHL]]) (2015–present) ; Indoor soccer [[Ontario Fury]] ([[Major Arena Soccer League|MASL]]) (2013–present) | seating_capacity = [[Basketball]]: 10,832
[[Ice hockey|Hockey]]: 9,736
[[Indoor soccer]]: 9,736{{cite web |title=Professional Arena Soccer League Coming to Citizens Business Bank Arena|url=http://www.pointstreaksites.com/view/proarenasoccerleague/news/news_73022|work=PASL Soccer |date=September 3, 2013|accessdate=September 3, 2013}}
[[Concerts]]:11,089 }} '''Citizens Business Bank Arena''' (originally '''Ontario Community Events Center''') is a multi-purpose [[arena]], in [[Ontario, California]], [[United States|USA]]. It hosts local sporting events and concerts. Construction officially began on March 7, 2007, and the arena was opened on October 18, 2008. It is suitable for indoor events, including basketball, ice hockey, ice shows, boxing, graduation ceremonies and concerts. The arena's basketball capacity is 10,832. It also seats 9,736 for hockey (9,491 for [[Ontario Reign]] games) and its full capacity is 11,089. The {{convert|225000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} venue also has 36 luxury suites on two levels.{{cite web |title=FACTS ABOUT CITIZENS BUSINESS BANK ARENA|url=https://www.cbbankarena.com/arena-info/faqs|accessdate=February 22, 2018}} It is the biggest and most modern arena within the [[Inland Empire (California)|Inland Empire]] region of California. The arena's construction cost was $150 million; however, it was debt free due to the city selling different properties throughout the city.{{cite news |title=Ontario's New Arena|first1=Vanessa|last1=Franko|first2=Kimberly|last2=Pierceall|url=http://www.pe.com/sports/basketball/lakers/stories/PE_News_Local_S_arena12.1eb9051.html|newspaper=[[The Press-Enterprise (California)|The Press-Enterprise]]|location=Riverside|date=October 13, 2008|accessdate=January 13, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100817073514/http://www.pe.com/sports/basketball/lakers/stories/PE_News_Local_S_arena12.1eb9051.html|archivedate=August 17, 2010|deadurl=yes}} It was constructed on the old [[Ontario Motor Speedway]] property.{{cite news |title=New Ontario Arena Gears Up for Concerts|first=Ben|last=Wener|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/citizens-business-bank-2220540-arena-ontario|newspaper=[[Orange County Register]]|date=November 7, 2008|accessdate=January 13, 2009}} The arena is owned by the city of Ontario and from 2008 to 2016 was operated by [[Anschutz Entertainment Group|AEG Worldwide]], since July 1, 2016, the arena is operated by [[SMG (property management)|SMG]].{{cite web |title=AEG Worldwide|url=http://www.aegworldwide.com/08_corporate/about_us.html|publisher=[[Anschutz Entertainment Group]]|accessdate=January 13, 2009}} The arena is home to the [[Ontario Reign (AHL)|Ontario Reign]] of the [[American Hockey League]], the [[Ontario Fury]] of the [[Major Arena Soccer League]] and the [[Agua Caliente Clippers]] of the [[NBA G League]]. ==Description== ===Name=== The arena's original name was '''Ontario Community Events Center''' when the arena was first announced in October 2006.{{cite web |title=Arena Announcement|url=http://www.ci.ontario.ca.us/index.cfm/4298/40026|publisher=City of Ontario|date=October 2, 2006|accessdate=January 13, 2009}} On October 20, 2006, it was announced that the city based bank, Citizens Business Bank, bought the naming right for the arena.{{cite web |title=Arena Faqs|url=http://www.cbbankarena.com/arena-info/faqs|publisher=Citizens Business Bank Arena|accessdate=October 31, 2011}} Citizens Business Bank is the largest locally-based financial institution in the region and California's eleventh largest bank.{{cite news |title=Ontario's Citizens Business Bank Faces More Competition As It Grows|first=Jonathan|last=Shikes|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-160730794.html|newspaper=[[The Press-Enterprise (California)|The Press-Enterprise]]|location=Riverside|date=March 18, 2007|accessdate=January 13, 2009}} ===Tenants=== In November 2007, it was announced that a new [[ECHL]] franchise would be playing at the arena starting in the [[2008–09 ECHL season|2008–09 season]].{{cite web |title=Pro Hockey Invades the Inland Empire|url=http://www.ontarioreign.com/news/teamnews/index.html?article_id=40|publisher=Ontario Reign|date=November 16, 2007|accessdate=January 13, 2009}} The arena became home of the [[Ontario Reign (ECHL)|Ontario Reign]], an affiliate of the [[Los Angeles Kings]].{{cite web |title=Ontario Set To Reign The Inland Empire|url=http://www.ontarioreign.com/news/teamnews/index.html?article_id=38|publisher=Ontario Reign|date=December 12, 2007|accessdate=January 13, 2009}} The ECHL Reign played their home games at the arena each season from 2008 to 2015.{{cite web |title=Reign Faqs|url=http://www.ontarioreign.com/gameday/faq/|publisher=Ontario Reign|accessdate=January 13, 2009}} In 2012, the arena was home to the [[Ontario Warriors]] of [[American Indoor Football]] but the team folded before the season ended.{{cite news |title=Ontario Warriors Will Begin Professional Football Competition Next Month; Team President Says: 'We Guarantee We'll Win the Championship'|first=Shel|last=Segal|url=http://www.fontanaheraldnews.com/articles/2012/02/12/news/doc4f385cac92949032063124.txt|newspaper=Fontana Herald News|date=February 12, 2012|accessdate=February 15, 2012}} Since 2013, the arena has been home of the [[Ontario Fury]] of the [[Major Arena Soccer League]]. In 2014 and 2015, the arena also hosted select home games of the [[Los Angeles D-Fenders]]. On January 29, 2015, the Los Angeles Kings announced that they would be moving their [[American Hockey League]] affiliate, the [[Manchester Monarchs (AHL)|Manchester Monarchs]], from [[Manchester, New Hampshire]], to Ontario. The team retained the [[Ontario Reign]] nickname from its ECHL predecessor. The ECHL's Reign moved to [[Manchester, New Hampshire]], and became the [[Manchester Monarchs (ECHL)|Monarchs]].{{cite web | url=http://www.ontarioreign.com/news/teamnews/?article_id=2455 | title=Reign Become the AHL Affiliate of LA Kings | publisher=[[Ontario Reign (ECHL)|Ontario Reign]] | date=January 30, 2015 | accessdate=January 31, 2015}} Starting in the [[2017–18 NBA G League season|2017–18]] season the arena became home of the [[Agua Caliente Clippers]], the [[NBA G League]] team of the [[Los Angeles Clippers]]. ==Events== The arena held its grand opening on October 18, 2008.{{cite web |title=Grand Opening Celebration|url=http://www.cbbankarena.com/default.asp?cbba=33&urlkeyword=event-detail&objId=410|publisher=Citizens Business Bank Arena|accessdate=September 16, 2008}} ===Basketball=== On October 24, 2008, its first event took place in front of a sold-out crowd of 10,316, for an NBA preseason game, where the [[Los Angeles Lakers]] defeated the [[Oklahoma City Thunder]] 105–94.{{cite news |title=Kobe Plays Fewer Than 8 Minutes, but Helps Lakers to Strong Start|agency=Associated Press|url=http://espn.go.com/nba/recap?id=281024013|work=[[ESPN]]|date=October 24, 2008|accessdate=October 31, 2011}} There has been a Lakers' preseason game every year at the arena with the exception of 2011 due to the [[2011 NBA lockout]]. [[File:Citizens Business Bank Arena photo D Ramey Logan.jpg|thumb|Citizens Business Bank Arena]] The arena was host of the inaugural games in the [[Junior Basketball Association]] on June 21, 2018, and is the host of the [[2018 JBA season|2018 JBA Championship]]. ===Hockey=== The Reign held its first game at the arena on October 25, 2008, against the [[Las Vegas Wranglers]] in front of a crowd of 8,832. The Reign won their first game at the arena 4–1.{{cite web |title=Reign Lasso In Wranglers With A 4-1 Win In Home Opener|url=http://www.ontarioreign.com/news/archives/index.html?article_id=110|publisher=Ontario Reign|date=October 25, 2008|accessdate=November 2, 2008}} On January 20, 2010, the arena hosted the [[2010 ECHL All-Star Game]] in front of 7,615 fans.{{cite news |title=Ontario Reign to Host ECHL All-Star Game in January [UPDATED]|first=Austin|last=Knoblauch|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/sports_blog/2009/08/ontario-reign-to-host-echl-allstar-game-during-olympic-break.html|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=August 28, 2009|accessdate=October 31, 2011}} The arena also hosted a preseason match between the [[Los Angeles Kings]] and the [[San Jose Sharks]].{{cite web |title=Sharks 2, Kings 1, SO|url=http://kings.nhl.com/club/recap.htm?id=2009010023|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]|date=September 23, 2009|accessdate=October 31, 2011}} ===Entertainment=== [[Carrie Underwood]] played the arena's first concert on November 9, 2008, with [[Little Big Town]] as her opening act.{{cite web |title=Carrie Underwood|url=http://www.cbbankarena.com/default.asp?cbba=33&urlkeyword=event-detail&objId=396|publisher=Citizens Business Bank Arena|accessdate=September 16, 2008}} [[United States|American]] [[heavy metal music|heavy metal]] band [[Metallica]] performed at the arena during their [[World Magnetic Tour]] on December 12, 2008, in front of a crowd of 10,959 and filmed part of their music video ''[[Broken, Beat & Scarred]]'' during the concert and also at the concert at the [[Save Mart Center]] in [[Fresno, California]], on December 13, 2008.{{cite web |title=Concert Box Score 2004-2010 Metallica|url=http://www.marksaw.com/music/boxscores/Metallica_2004-2010.html|publisher=Marksaw.com|accessdate=November 3, 2011}}{{cite web |title=Blabbermouth.net - Metallica: Release Date Announced For French Concert DVD|url=http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=122773|publisher=RoadRunner Records|accessdate=November 3, 2011}} The arena has also hosted [[Bill Gaither (gospel singer)|Bill Gaither]], [[Larry the Cable Guy]], [[Vicente Fernández]], [[Sade Adu|Sade]], [[Justin Bieber]], [[Earth, Wind & Fire]], [[Chicago (band)|Chicago]], [[Elton John]], [[Eagles (band)|The Eagles]], [[Disney on Ice]], [[Playhouse Disney]] Live, [[Sesame Street Live]], The [[Harlem Globetrotters]], [[Bob Dylan]], [[Scorpions (band)|Scorpions]], [[Neil Diamond]], [[André Rieu]], [[American Idols LIVE! Tour 2009|American Idol Live!]], [[Trace Adkins]], [[Alan Jackson]], [[Pitbull (rapper)|Pitbull]], [[Dancing With the Stars]], [[Stars on Ice]], [[Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus]], and other events.{{cite web |title=Arena Previous events|url=http://www.cbbankarena.com/default.asp?cbba=96|publisher=Citizens Business Bank Arena|accessdate=July 6, 2010}} On September 1, 2013, the arena was the site where Mexican singers [[Joan Sebastian]] and Ezequiel Peña sang together for the first time ever. The [[American Idols LIVE! Tour 2011]] was held on July 16, 2011. English singer [[Sade Adu|Sade]] recorded her [[Bring Me Home Live 2011]] DVD at the arena on September 4, 2011. On October 29, 2012, [[Katy Perry]] did a private concert at the arena for the San Manuel Indian Tribe. During her [[Blown Away Tour]], country music singer [[Carrie Underwood]] filmed [[The Blown Away Tour: Live]] DVD at the arena on March 3, 2013, the concert also aired live on [[AXS TV]].{{cite web |title=Carrie Underwood Concert DVD Due Aug. 13|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1708304/carrie-underwood-concert-dvd-due-aug-13.jhtml?rsspartner=rssMozilla|work=CMT.com|date=September 3, 2013|accessdate=September 3, 2013}} During the summer of 2013, [[Selena Gomez]] used the arena to rehearse for her [[Stars Dance Tour]].[http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1712077/selena-gomez-stars-dance-tour-rehearsal.jhtml Exclusive: Take A Peek At Selena Gomez's Stars Dance World Tour! - Music, Celebrity, Artist News | MTV.com] On July 5, 2014, [[Cher]] did a stop here on her [[Dressed to Kill Tour (Cher)|Dressed to Kill Tour]] with her very special guest [[Cyndi Lauper]]. ===Boxing, Wrestling and MMA=== Since its opening, the arena has hosted many boxing events. The first boxing event was on November 28, 2008, with two fights, [[Chris Arreola]] vs. [[Travis Walker]] and [[Paul Williams (boxer)|Paul Williams]] vs. [[Verno Phillips]].{{cite web |title=Paul Williams vs Verno Phillips and Chris Arreola vs Travis Walker: On HBO|first=Nathan|last=Aguilar|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/86106-paul-williams-vs-verno-phillips-and-chris-arreola-vs-travis-walker-on-hbo|work=[[Bleacher Report]]|date=November 25, 2008|accessdate=July 6, 2010}} On December 5, 2009, the arena hosted a women's title fight between champion [[Kina Malpartida]] and Lyndsey Scragg.{{cite web |title=Peru's National Hero Kina Malpartida Defends Title|first=David A.|last=Avila|url=http://www.thesweetscience.com/boxing-article/7484/peru-national-hero-kina-malpartida-defends-title/|work=The Sweet Science|date=December 2, 2009|accessdate=July 6, 2010}} On April 24, 2010, the arena was the venue where [[Tomasz Adamek]] defeated Chris Arreola to retain the [[International Boxing Federation|IBF]] International Heavyweight Title.{{cite news |title=Adamek Wins Majority Decision Over Arreola|agency=Associated Press|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/news/story?id=5134198|work=[[ESPN]]|date=April 25, 2010|accessdate=July 6, 2010}} The arena also hosted an [[Friday Night Fights|ESPN Friday Night Fights]] event on July 2, 2010, with the main event being [[Demetrius Hopkins]] vs. [[Mike Arnaoutis]].{{cite web |title=Demetrius Hopkins Wins Fight, Contreras Wins Too|url=http://www.thesweetscience.com/boxing-article/8139/demetrius-hopkins-wins-fight-contreras-wins-too/|work=The Sweet Science|date=July 3, 2010|accessdate=July 6, 2010}} On August 13, 2010, Friday Night Fights returned to the arena with a fight between [[Chris Arreola]] and [[Manuel Quezada]].{{cite web |title=Arreola to Face Quezada on Aug. 13|first=Dan|last=Rafael|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/news/story?id=5358348|work=[[ESPN]]|date=July 6, 2010|accessdate=July 6, 2010}} On July 14, 2012, Mexican female boxer Mariana "La Barbie" Juarez defended her [[List of WBC female world champions#Flyweight|Flyweight]] title against Japanese boxer Shindo Go; the bout was broadcast on Mexican channel [[Televisa]] [[XHGC-TV|Canal 5]] series ''Sábados de Corona''.{{cite web |title=Ovëishon Presents Three World Boxing Championships Sanctioned by the WBC at the Citizens Business Bank Arena|url=http://www.cbbankarena.com/default.asp?cbba=65&objId=142|publisher=Citizens Business Bank Arena|date=June 25, 2012|accessdate=October 29, 2012}} On November 24, 2012, [[Robert Guerrero]] successfully defended his interim [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] [[Welterweight]] title against [[Andre Berto]] at the arena.{{cite news |title=Andre Berto, Robert Guerrero to Fight Nov. 24 in Ontario|first=Lance|last=Pugmire|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/oct/23/sports/la-sp-sn-boxing-berto-guerrero-20121023|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=October 23, 2012|accessdate=October 29, 2012}} The arena hosted [[Andre Ward]] vs [[Edwin Rodríguez (boxer)|Edwin Rodríguez]] on November 16, 2013.http://boxrec.com/show/678538 On March 13, 2015, the first [[Premier Boxing Champions|PBC on Spike]] event was held at the venue with main event being [[Andre Berto]] vs [[Josesito López]].http://espn.go.com/boxing/story/_/id/12480385/former-welterweight-titlist-andre-berto-defeats-josesito-lopez-sixth-round-tko Since 2010, the arena has been the Inland Empire's stop for [[WWE]], replacing the smaller [[Coussoulis Arena]] in [[San Bernardino, California|San Bernardino]]. The arena has hosted various ''WWE Live'' events and various tapings for ''[[WWE Raw]]'' and ''[[WWE SmackDown|SmackDown]]''.{{cite web |title=WWE Supershow House Show Results (12/05/10) - Ontario, California|url=http://www.wrestlingnewsworld.com/wwe-house-show-results/wwe-supershow-house-show-results-12-05-10-2.php|work=Wrestling News World|date=December 5, 2010|accessdate=October 30, 2011}}{{cite web |title=2/25 WWE Results Ontario, Calif.: Punk Defends WWE Title in Three-Way Main Event, Eve Promo & Miz Backs Eve, Funk is Back Night 2|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/Arena_Reports_10/article_58565.shtml|work=PWTorch|date=February 25, 2010|accessdate=March 12, 2012}}{{cite web |title=Update On Undertaker's In-Ring Future, WWE Interested In ROH Talents, Recent Attendance|url=http://www.wrestlinginc.com/wi/news/2012/0229/550208/the-undertaker/|work=Wrestling Inc.|date=February 29, 2012|accessdate=March 12, 2009}}{{cite web |title=WWE SmackDown Ontario|url=http://www.wwe.com/events/wwepresents-smackdown-ONTARIO|work=WWE|date=November 22, 2013|accessdate=November 22, 2013}}{{cite web |title= WWE SMACKDOWN COMES TO THE Inland Empire on FEBRUARY 11, 2014 |url=http://www.cbbankarena.com/news/detail/wwe-smackdown-comes-to-the-inland-empire-on-february-11-2014|work=CBBankArena.com|date=November 22, 2013|accessdate=November 22, 2013}} The ''Smackdown/Main Event'' tapings on February 11, 2014 were the first time WWE televised an event from the Inland Empire since they taped four editions of ''[[WWE Raw]]'' at the [[Orange Pavilion]] in San Bernardino on April 1, 1996. The arena has also been host to many [[Mixed martial arts]] events including [[Bellator Fighting Championships]]. On August 10, 2013, the arena hosted [[World Series of Fighting: Spong vs. DeAnda|WSOF 4: Spong vs. DeAnda]]. The arena also hosts various events of MMA promotion [[King of the Cage]], which has its headquarters in nearby [[Rancho Cucamonga]]. From 2014 to 2017, the arena hosted the annual [[CIF Southern Section]] Boys Masters Wrestling Championships. In 2018 the event was also scheduled to be held at the arena but was moved to [[Temecula Valley High School]], where the event was previously held, due to scheduling conflicts.http://cifss.org/sport-news/2014-boys-masters-wrestling-meet/http://www.latimes.com/socal/daily-pilot/sports/tn-dpt-sp-masters-wrestling-20180223-story.html ===Other events=== The venue hosted a [[Professional Bull Riders|PBR]] [[Built Ford Tough Series]] [[bull riding]] event in late September 2009 and also hosted another event on August 29 and August 30, 2010.{{cite web |title=PBR Heads West for Dickies Invitational in Ontario, California|url=http://www.pbr.com/en/news/press-releases/2009/9/pbr-heads-west-for-dickies-invitational-in-ontario,-california.aspx|publisher=[[Professional Bull Riders]]|date=September 1, 2009|accessdate=October 30, 2011}} The arena was the site of the [[2011 Skate America|2011 edition]] of [[Skate America]] from October 21 to the 23rd.{{cite web |title=Ontario, Calif., Selected to host 2011 Skate America|url=http://www.cbbankarena.com/default.asp?cbba=65&objId=104|publisher=Citizens Business Bank Arena|date=March 3, 2011|accessdate=October 31, 2011}} The arena is used for high school graduation ceremonies from the Fontana Unified School District, the Rialto Unified School District, the Chino Valley Unified School District and the Upland Unified School District in late May/early June. ==References== {{Reflist|2|refs= {{cite web |title=SMG to Manage Citizens Business Bank Arena; Will Ontario Reign Remain?|url=http://arenadigest.com/2016/06/16/smg-to-manage-citizens-business-bank-arena-will-ontario-reign-remain/|publisher=arenadigest.com|accessdate=June 30, 2016}} }} ==External links== {{commons category}} *[http://www.cbbankarena.com/ Official website] {{S-start-collapsible|header={{S-sta|et}}}} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[Ontario Reign (AHL)|Ontario Reign]] (AHL) | years = 2015 – future | before =[[Verizon Wireless Arena]] (as the [[Manchester Monarchs (AHL)|Manchester Monarchs]]) | after = current }} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[Ontario Reign (ECHL)|Ontario Reign]] (ECHL) | years = 2008 – 2015 | before = [[Ford Arena]] (as the [[Texas Wildcatters]]) | after = [[Verizon Wireless Arena]] (as the [[Manchester Monarchs (ECHL)|Manchester Monarchs]]) }} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[ECHL All-Star Game]] | years = [[2010 ECHL All-Star Game|2010]] | before = [[Sovereign Center]] | after = [[Rabobank Arena]] }} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[Los Angeles Temptation]] | years = 2011 – 2014 | before = [[Los Angeles Memorial Sports Arena]] | after = [[Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum]] }} {{end}} {{Ontario Reign}} {{AHL Arenas}} {{NBA G-League arenas}} {{MASL Arenas}} {{coord|34.072947|-117.566401|region:US_type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in California]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2008]] [[Category:Sports in Ontario, California]] [[Category:Sports venues in San Bernardino County, California]] [[Category:Sports venues in the Inland Empire]] [[Category:Basketball venues in California]] [[Category:Boxing venues in California]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in California]] [[Category:Indoor soccer venues in California]] [[Category:Mixed martial arts venues in California]] [[Category:Professional wrestling venues in California]] [[Category:Wrestling venues in California]] [[Category:Legends Football League venues]] [[Category:NBA G League arenas]] [[Category:2008 establishments in California]]

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Clermont Avenue Skating Rink | nickname = | image = Clermont Avenue Skating Rink.jpg | caption = Interior of the Clermont Avenue Skating Rink. | fullname = | location = Clermont Avenue, [[Brooklyn, New York]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = mechanically frozen ice | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Brooklyn Skating Club]] 1896–1906
[[Brooklyn Crescents]] 1896–1906 | seating_capacity = | dimensions = 70x175 feet }} The '''Clermont Avenue Skating Rink''' was a sports [[arena]] on Clermont Avenue in [[Brooklyn, New York]], United States. It was home to the [[Brooklyn Skating Club]] and the [[Brooklyn Crescents]] of the [[American Amateur Hockey League]] from 1896 to 1906. The ice hockey team of the Brooklyn Skating Club folded in 1906 and the Brooklyn Crescents went on to play at the [[St. Nicholas Rink]] in [[Manhattan]] for the 1906–07 season as the Clermont Avenue Skating Rink instead was used for roller hockey. {{DEFAULTSORT:Clermont Avenue Skating Rink}} [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Brooklyn]] [[Category:Defunct indoor arenas in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1916]]

{{Other uses|Lloydminster Centennial Civic Centre}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Innovation Credit Union iPlexhttp://www.swiftcurrent.ca/divisions/community-services/recreation/recreational-facilities/credit-union-i-plex | nickname = | image = | location = 2001 Chaplin Street East
[[Swift Current]], [[Saskatchewan]]
S9H 5A8 | broke_ground = April 5, 1965{{cite news |title=Mayor Turns Sod for Civic Centre|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=udxUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WjwNAAAAIBAJ&pg=5335,1092711&dq=en|newspaper=[[Leader-Post]]|location=Regina|date=April 6, 1965|accessdate=October 18, 2013}} | built = | opened = January 24, 1967{{cite news |title=Opening of Civic Centre Climax to Years of Work|first=Elaine|last=Jacobs|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=fuNUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cjwNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1462,3972674&dq=en|newspaper=[[Leader-Post]]|location=Regina|date=January 25, 1967|accessdate=October 18, 2013}} | expanded = 2007-2008 | closed = | demolished = | owner = City of Swift Current | operator = City of Swift Current | surface = Hockey | construction_cost = [[Canadian dollar|{{dollarsign|CAD}}]]750,000
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|CA|750000|1967}}}} in {{Inflation-year|CA}} dollars{{inflation-fn|CA}}) | architect = R. B. Ramsay{{cite news |title=Civic Centre Contract Let|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NdxUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UjwNAAAAIBAJ&pg=3652,2116914&dq=en|newspaper=[[Leader-Post]]|location=Regina|date=March 13, 1965|accessdate=October 17, 2013}} | general_contractor = Rittinger Construction Company, Ltd. | seating_capacity = [[Ice hockey]]: 2,879 (3,239 with standing room) | former_names = Centennial Civic Centre (1967–2008) | tenants = [[Swift Current Broncos]] ([[Western Hockey League|WHL]]) (1967–1974, 1986–present)
[[Swift Current Rampage]] ([[Prairie Gold Lacrosse League|PGLL]]) (2003–present)
Swift Current Legionnaires ([[Saskatchewan Midget AAA Hockey League|SMAAAHL]]) }} The '''Innovation Credit Union iPlex''' is a 2,879-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Swift Current]], [[Saskatchewan]], Canada. The arena was built in 1967 as a [[Canadian Centennial]] project and originally known as the Centennial Civic Centre. In 2007, Swift Current city council approved a $14 million expansion to the Centennial Civic Centre. Construction of the hockey/curling complex was completed in the fall of 2007. It is home to the [[Swift Current Broncos]] [[ice hockey]] team, [[Home Hardware]] AAA Midget Legionnaires [[ice hockey]] team, and [[Swift Current Rampage]] lacrosse team, it hosted the [[2010 World Women's Curling Championship]] as well as the [[2016 Ford World Women's Curling Championship]]. The naming rights are held by [[Innovation Credit Union]].http://www.swiftcurrent.ca/divisions/community-services/recreation/recreational-facilities/credit-union-i-plex ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.city.swift-current.sk.ca/leisure.php?name=Sections&op=viewarticle&artid=201 Credit Union i-plex - City of Swift Current] {{WHL Arenas}} {{Coord|50.286652|-107.7715|type:landmark|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Credit Union Iplex}} [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Canada]] [[Category:Indoor lacrosse venues in Canada]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Saskatchewan]] [[Category:Sports venues in Saskatchewan]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Swift Current]] [[Category:Western Hockey League arenas]] [[Category:1967 establishments in Saskatchewan]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1967]] {{Saskatchewan-struct-stub}} {{Canada-icehockey-venue-stub}}

revision.comment: Added one more country on a list
revision.text:
{{distinguish|Cycle ball}} {{infobox sport | image = Bike Polo AUT-HUN.jpg | imagesize = 250px | caption = Bike polo match in [[Budapest]] | union = [[International Bicycle Polo Federation]], [[North American Bike Polo Association]], [[European Hardcourt Bike Polo Association]] | nickname = | first = October 1891 - [[County Wicklow]], Ireland. (Rathclaren Rovers V Ohne Hast Cycling Club) | team = Five or Three | mgender = | category = [[Team sport]] | equipment = [[Bicycle]], [[Mallet]], [[Ball]] | venue = | olympic = London, 1908. (Demonstration Game – Ireland 3-v-1 Germany) }} '''Cycle polo''' is a [[team sport]], similar to traditional [[polo]], except that [[bicycle]]s are used instead of horses. There are 2 versions of the sport: grass and [[Hardcourt Bike Polo]]. The hardcourt game has seen a sharp spike in interest as of 2007{{cite web | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/8177668.stm | title=Polo's young punk cousin | publisher=BBC | date=31 July 2009 | accessdate=10 June 2015}} and new teams are sprouting up across the world - in China, Canada, Ireland, Switzerland, France, India, Germany, Pakistan, Malaysia, Sri Lanka, Indonesia, Hungary, Australia, New Zealand, Sweden, England, Scotland, Argentina, Italy, Spain, USA, Poland, Croatia, Slovenia, Lithuania, Nepal, Brazil and Cuba. == The Traditional game == Traditional cycle polo is played in a rectangular grass field, 150 meters by 100 meters officially, unofficially whatever field is big enough. Moreover, official dimensions can vary between 120 and 150 meters in length on 80 to 100 meters in width. The ball used approximately 2.5 inches in diameter and the mallet is of length 1 meter. There are 6 members (7 in France) on a team of which 4 (5 in France) are on field at a time. The other two are used as substitutes. International matches are played for a duration of 30 minutes divided into periods of 7.5 minutes each called as a ''chukkar''. Extra time can be used to determine the winner in case the scores are tied at normal time. If a deliberate foul is committed at the vicinity of the goal, the team that is fouled is automatically given a goal. Less severe fouls are awarded 15 metre and 25 metre free hits. In the event of deliberate fouls or dangerous fouls, the umpire can issue the Yellow card (warning) and in case of repeated or severe fouls the Red card (ejection). The ejected player can be replaced by a substitute after the end of the current ''chukkar'' if the umpire allows it. == The Hardcourt game == [[File:Bike polo.ogv|thumb|320px|Video of cycle polo]] {{main article|Hardcourt Bike Polo}} In recent years, an alternate form of the game known as "[[Hardcourt Bike Polo]]" has grown in popularity. In this variation, teams composed of three players compete on tennis courts, street hockey rinks, or whatever other surfaces are available. The rules vary slightly by city. Generally this is a faster game with 3 members on a team, no substitutions, and all members are on the court at all times. A [[street hockey]] ball is used and matches are played until one team scores 5 points or time has expired, without playing chukkars. During tournament play a time limit, such as 10 minutes, may be used to maximize the number of tournament rounds possible during the day. There are three core rules of play: In the case of a 'foot down' or 'dab' (touching the ground with one's foot) the player must "tap out" by riding to mid-court and hitting a designated area with their mallet. There is usually a tap-out located on either side of the court. In order to score, the offensive player must hit the ball across the goal line using the narrow end of the mallet - called a "shot" or "hit." Hitting the ball across the goal line with the wide end of the mallet is called a "shuffle". When your team scores a goal, you wait back in your end for the other team (player or ball, whichever comes first) to cross half before engaging in play again. The [[North American Hardcourt Bike Polo Association]] has created an official ruleset,[http://www.nahardcourt.com/rules Official North American ruleset] which has helped standardize rules across the globe. == History == The game was invented in County Wicklow, Ireland, in 1891 by retired champion cyclist [[Richard J. Mecredy]], editor of ''The Irish Cyclist'' magazine.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/london/hi/people_and_places/2012/newsid_8845000/8845620.stm Could a lost Olympic sport find its way back to London? BBC 23 July 2010 article - retrieved 27 July 2013] In October of that year the first cycle polo match was played at the Scalp (County Wicklow) between ''Rathclaren Rovers'' and the ''Ohne Hast Cycling Club''.{{cite web|author=polovelo |url=http://www.polo-velo.net/english/history/history.htm |title=Cycle polo story |publisher=Polo-velo.net |date= |accessdate=2010-10-01}} Towards the end of the 19th century the game reached Great Britain, France, and the United States where the [[American Star Bicycle]] was a popular mount.{{cite book | last = Herlihy | first = David V. | title = Bicycle, The History | publisher = Yale University Press | year = 2004 | pages = 372 | isbn = 0-300-10418-9}} The first international match was played between Ireland and England in 1901. Cycle polo was a demonstration sport at the [[1908 Olympics|1908 London Olympics]] with Ireland winning the gold, beating Germany.{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/sports/ath041908.htm |title=Welcome to rediff.com : Sports - Athens 2004 History |publisher=Rediff.com |date= |accessdate=2010-10-01}}{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/olympics_2004/history/3054406.stm |title=BBC SPORT | Olympics 2004 | History | London 1908 |publisher=BBC News |date=2004-07-09 |accessdate=2010-10-01}} The sport reached its peak of popularity in Great Britain during the 1930s with the introduction of the regional leagues. Cycle polo also flourished in France during this period with the establishment of the French league. Internationals between France and Great Britain were held regularly. However the Second World War marked the beginning of the demise of cycle polo in Britain. The sport remained in France though, with league championships held regularly until today. The 1980s saw the rise of two new powers in cycle polo, India and United States. The Bicycle Polo Association of America was created in 1994. International cycle polo matches staged a comeback in the 1990s with the first world championship organized in 1996 in the USA. Today there is organized cycle polo being played in Brazil, Argentina, Australia, Canada, France, Germany, Great Britain, India, Ireland, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Sweden, Switzerland and USA. Cycle polo was officially recognized by the [[Union Cycliste Internationale]] in 2001. == Cycle Polo in India == [[File:Cycle Polo 18 3.jpg|thumb|A Traditional Cycle Polo game in [[Calcutta Cricket and Football Club | CC&FC]], [[ Kolkata]]]] The Cycle Polo Association of India was officially created in 1966 it has its office in [[Jaipur]], [[Rajasthan]]. The first men's nationals were played in 1970 in [[New Delhi]], with the team from Rajasthan emerging victorious. In the 2016-17 season, the men's nationals was held in [[Jodhpur]], [[Rajasthan]] from 13th Jan 2017 to 16th Jan 2017. [[Indian Air Force]] was the champion and Indian Army were the runners-up. The 2016-17 women's nationals was held at [[Dundlod]], [[Rajasthan]] from 21st Feb 2017 to 24th Feb 2017. [[Chhattisgarh]] defeated [[Karnataka]] in the finals.{{cite web|last1=Cycle Polo Federation of India|title=Official Website|url=http://www.cyclepolo.com/achivements%20of%20cycle%20polo1.html|accessdate=6 April 2018}} The [[Calcutta Cricket and Football Club|Calcutta Cricket & Football Club]] hosted the first Merchant’s Cup Cycle Polo tournament in 1973. In 2012, the [[Calcutta Cricket and Football Club|CC&FC]] had organised a Cycle Polo Legend's Tournament where great players of yesteryear such as Vijai Singh, Lakshman Singh and Bikram Das participated. {{cite news|last1=Dey|first1=Sreyoshi|title=The wheels of a royal sport were a turnin’ at CC&fc|url=https://www.telegraphindia.com/1120612/jsp/entertainment/story_15597503.jsp|accessdate=16 March 2018|agency=ABP|issue=The Telegraph|date=12 June 2012}} Currently, the [[Calcutta Cricket and Football Club|CC&FC]] plays host to the March Mug, the Swaroop Bhanjdeo Memorial Tournament and the CC&FC Trophy. Since 2015 onwards, [[Calcutta Cricket and Football Club|CC&FC]] has been hosting the CC&FC All India Invitation Cycle Polo Cup which is organised jointly by the CC&FC along with the Cycle Polo Association of Bengal. In 2017, the '''CC&FC All India Invitation Cycle Polo Cup''' had 7 teams in the men's section and 5 in the women's section. Territorial Army were the eventual champions in the men's section. They defeated [[Indian Air Force]] 14:6 in the final. In the women section [[Chhattisgarh]] defeating in [[West Bengal|Bengal]] in the final. 15:3 was the score line. {{cite news|last1=Sarkar|first1=Brinda|title=A power-packed cycle polo tourney at CC&FC|url=https://www.telegraphindia.com/1170601/jsp/t2/story_154432.jsp|accessdate=6 April 2018|agency=ABP|issue=The Telegraph|date=1 June 2017}} In 2018, in the men's section, the defending champions Territorial Army successfully defended their title by defeating [[West Bengal|Bengal]] 12:10 in the final. In the women's section, [[West Bengal|Bengal]] easily overcame their opponents [[Uttar Pradesh]] 15:0 in the final. Cycle Polo Federation of India received a funding of 2.75 million rupees from central government in 2013 - 14. {{cite web|last1=Walia|first1=Shelly|title=Shootingball, cycle polo and other obscure sports funded by the Indian government|url=https://scroll.in/article/693190/shootingball-cycle-polo-and-other-obscure-sports-funded-by-the-indian-government|website=Scroll|accessdate=6 April 2018}} == International Bicycle Polo Championships == {| class="toccolours" border="1" cellpadding="2" style="border-collapse: collapse; text-align: center; width: 80%; margin: 0 auto;" |- style="background: #efefef;" !width=10%|Year !width=18%|Host ! style="width:24%; background:gold;"|Gold ! style="width:24%; background:silver;"|Silver ! style="width:24%; background:#c96;"|Bronze |- style="background:#f5faff;" |'''1996''' |{{flagicon|USA}}

France |} The UK based [http://www.pukkachukkas.com/bike%20polo.html Pukka Chukkas] won the 2012 Acumen Energy Bicycle Polo Cup held at Tiger Tops Karnali on the fringes of the Bardia National Park in Nepal, beating EFG Switzerland in a thrilling final in front of a crowd of over 5,000. The bicycles used in the tournament were donated to local schools and social clubs, and money was raised for the prevention and cure of elephant tuberculosis. == European Championships == The European Championships is an annual Bicycle Polo competition for European club teams. It is held over three legs each year in France, Ireland and Britain. The competition began in 2007 following the compromise between French and British/Irish traditional rules. V.C. Frileuse-Sanvic of France were crowned champions of the inaugural competition. * 2007 Won by V.C. Frileuse-Sanvic, France * 2008 Won by St-Pierre de Varengeville, France == See also == * [[Cycle ball]] * [[Hardcourt Bike Polo]] * [[Polo]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.worldbicyclepolo.com/ International Bicycle Polo Federation] * [http://www.polo-velo.net/english/history/history.htm Timeline of Bike Polo History] * [https://archive.org/details/BikePoloInGalwayIrelandInThe1930s Hardcourt polo in the 1930s in Galway, Ireland (interview)] {{Team Sport}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cycle Polo}} [[Category:Cycle polo| ]] [[Category:Team sports]] [[Category:Ball games]] [[Category:Sports originating in Ireland]] [[Category:Cycle sport|polo]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]]
