{{refimprove|date=June 2012}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Hinkle Fieldhouse | nickname = ''Indiana's Basketball Cathedral'' | image = [[File:Hinklefieldhouse5.JPG|250px]] | fullname = | location = 510 West 49th Street
[[Indianapolis|Indianapolis, IN]] 46208, [[United States|USA]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = 1927 | opened = March 7, 1928 | renovated = 1989, 2011–2014 | demolished = | owner = [[Butler University]] | operator = Butler University | surface = Hardwood | construction_cost = $750,000
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|750000|1928}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = Fermor Spencer Cannon | former_names = Butler Fieldhouse (1928–1966) | tenants = [[Butler Bulldogs]] ([[Big East Conference|Big East]]) (1928–present)
[[Indianapolis Jets]] ([[Basketball Association of America|BAA]]) (1948–1949)
[[Indianapolis Olympians]] ([[National Basketball Association|NBA]]) (1949–1953)
[[1987 Pan-American Games]] | seating_capacity = 9,100 (2014–present)
10,000 (2009–2014)
11,043 (1989–2009)
15,000 (1928–1989) {{Infobox NRHP | embed = yes | name = Butler Fieldhouse | nrhp_type = nhl | image = HinkleNationalHistoriclandmark.JPG | caption = National Historic Landmark Plaque | locmapin = USA Indianapolis#Indiana#USA | coordinates = {{coord|39|50|37|N|86|10|2|W|display=inline,title}} | area = | built = 1927 | architect = Cannon, Fermor S. | added = December 22, 1983{{NRISref|2006a}} | designated_nrhp_type= February 27, 1987{{cite web|url=http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=1861&ResourceType=Building|title=Butler Fieldhouse|accessdate=2008-10-18|work=National Historic Landmark summary listing|publisher=National Park Service|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090114011554/http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=1861&ResourceType=Building|archivedate=2009-01-14|df=}} | governing_body = Private | refnum = 83003573 }} }} '''Hinkle Fieldhouse''' is a [[basketball]] arena located on the campus of [[Butler University]] in [[Indianapolis]], [[Indiana]], [[United States]]. When built in 1928, it was the largest basketball arena in the United States, a distinction it retained until 1950. It is the sixth-oldest college basketball arena still in use, and it is a U.S. [[National Historic Landmark]]. It is among the earliest of the major college fieldhouses, which, along with rules changes that made for a faster game, transformed college basketball in the late 1920s and 1930s. Hinkle Fieldhouse is nicknamed '''"Indiana's Basketball Cathedral"''' due to the rich history it has played in the development of basketball in Indiana, also to distinguish it from The [[Palestra]], known as "The Cathedral of College Basketball." ==History== Hinkle Fieldhouse and the 36,000-seat [[Butler Bowl]] football stadium were two of the first buildings erected when the university moved to the Fairview campus. The facilities were promoted by a corporation of 41 Indianapolis businessmen who viewed it as a prize for the city as well as for Butler. When Butler signed a lease with the [[Indiana High School Athletic Association]] to host the high school state tournament, the corporation agreed to finance the building at a cost of $1,000,000. In 1933, the interior was reconfigured, moving the court from an east-west orientation to a north-south position. In the initial arrangement, over half of the seats were at the ends of the court, while event viewing is typically better from the sides. [[Butler Bulldogs men's basketball|Butler]] hosted the high school tourney from 1928 to 1971, except for 1943–1945, when the building housed the US Army Air Forces and US Navy as a barracks during [[World War II]]. Hinkle Fieldhouse hosted the annual state [[Indiana High School Boy's Basketball Tournament|high school basketball championship]] games, including the ''[[Milan miracle|Milan Miracle]]'', the memorable [[1954 Milan High School basketball team|1954 victory]] of tiny [[Milan High School (Indiana)|Milan High School]] over the much larger [[Muncie Central High School]]. The film ''[[Hoosiers (film)|Hoosiers]]'' is loosely based on that event and used Hinkle Fieldhouse and the memorable voices of original announcers [[Hilliard Gates]] and [[Tom Carnegie]] in filming the climactic game of the popular movie.[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/17/sports/ncaabasketball/17butler.html?ref=sports Branch, John. "It's the Bricks That Make Butler Basketball Special," ''[[The New York Times]]'', Wednesday, March 17, 2010.] Ralph Underwood was the radio announcer. With the exception of an occasional high school showcase, high school basketball games are rarely contested at Hinkle Fieldhouse any more, and [[Indiana High School Athletic Association]] state basketball tournament games are played elsewhere. A major $1.5 million facelift in 1989 reduced the [[seating capacity]] from 15,000 to 11,043, as well as renovating the main reception area, basketball offices, film rooms and team locker rooms. The other athletic and physical education offices, sports locker rooms, and fitness facilities at the fieldhouse were renovated as well in 1992. Hinkle Fieldhouse hosted the entire 1994 [[Horizon League]] men's basketball conference tournament as well as parts of the 2004, 2008, 2009, and 2010 Horizon League tournaments. The fieldhouse was originally called '''Butler Fieldhouse''', but was renamed in 1966 to honor [[Tony Hinkle|Paul D. "Tony" Hinkle]] (1899–1992), who was basketball coach at Butler for 41 seasons ending in 1970. In 1983, it was placed on the National Register of Historic Places, and on February 27, 1987, it was designated as a [[National Historic Landmark]] in recognition of its role in transforming college basketball.{{cite web|url={{NHLS url|id=83003573}} |title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory-Nomination: Butler Fieldhouse / Hinkle Fieldhouse| date=October 1985 |author=James H. Charleton |publisher=National Park Service}} and {{NHLS url| id=83003573| title=Accompanying photo, exterior, undated| photos=y}} It also inspired the design of [[Bankers Life Fieldhouse]].{{cite news| last=Rabjohns| first=Jeff| date=November 6, 2009| title=Conseco Fieldhouse an Indiana Shrine By Design| url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/indystar/doc/241029610.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Nov+6%2C+2009&author=Rabjohns%2C+Jeff&pub=Indianapolis+Star&edition=&startpage=A.1&desc=An+Indiana+shrine+by+design| work=[[The Indianapolis Star]]| page=A1| subscription=yes}} In 2006, to celebrate Butler University's 150th anniversary, a documentary about Hinkle Fieldhouse aired on [[ESPN]] entitled ''Indiana's Basketball Cathedral''. === Renovation === In 2011, Butler University began the first phase of a renovation and restoration project. Capacity has been cut from 10,000 to 9,100. The gym that once held bleachers now has about 4,500 chair back seats and handrails line the aisles. That includes nearly all of the lower two levels except for some bleachers reserved for student seating. Small scoreboards occupy each of the four corners in addition to the main video board above midcourt. A pool was attached to the west end of Hinkle, but the university closed it in 2002 due to the high maintenance costs. The athletic department had been using it since then as a storage area. During the renovation, the pool was converted into a three-level facility that includes a workout room on the first level, an academic center and a training facility on the second floor that is six times larger than the previous training facility, and Butler's athletic administrative offices and coaches' offices on the top level. The men's and women's basketball offices are adjacent to their respective locker rooms just off the Hinkle floor, but they have been upgraded. The men's basketball locker room has been expanded and Butler has a separate video room for the first time. Former Butler standout and current [[Boston Celtics]] player [[Gordon Hayward]] donated the funds for the renovation. "The scoreboards on the side are new, but it still has a historic feel," Butler senior guard Alex Barlow said. "It still has a lot of modern upgrades that fans like to see. If you see the locker room and the weight room and the training room, it's come a long way since I've gotten here."https://www.indystar.com/story/sports/college/butler/2014/10/30/hinkle-fieldhouse-keeps-charm-renovation/18210121/ The Bulldogs still play on the original floor, which has been used longer than any playing surface in Division I. ==Events== The Fieldhouse has hosted to U.S. presidents ([[Herbert Hoover]], [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]], [[Richard Nixon]], [[Gerald Ford]], [[George H.W. Bush]], and [[Bill Clinton]]), Evangelist [[Billy Graham]], ice shows, professional basketball teams, Olympic basketball trials, the first USSR-USA basketball game, all-star basketball games for the [[NBA]], [[American Basketball Association|ABA]] and the East-West College All-Stars, national indoor track events, tennis matches of both [[Bill Tilden]] and [[Jack Kramer]], national equestrian events, the roller derby, a six-day bicycle race, a three ring circus, as well as the volleyball matches during the [[1987 Pan American Games]]. The [[1940 NCAA Basketball Tournament]] East Regionals were held there, won by the eventual national champion [[Indiana Hoosiers men's basketball|Indiana Hoosiers]]. Until 1978, those games were the only NCAA tournament games held within the city. With 15,000 spectators, the volleyball match was the highest-attended volleyball match ever held in the United States. ==See also== {{Portal|Indiana|Indianapolis|Basketball}} *[[Palestra]] *[[Rose Hill Gymnasium]] ==Gallery== File:HinkleConstruction 02.JPG|The floor of Hinkle Fieldhouse File:HinkleConstruction 03.JPG|The south side of Hinkle Fieldhouse during renovation File:HinkleConstruction 01.JPG|The east facade of Hinkle Fieldhouse during renovation File:ButlerGonzaga2013 15.JPG|The National Anthem prior to the Butler-Gonzaga game, January 19, 2013 File:ButlerGonzaga2013 21.JPG|Students flood the court following the buzzer-beater victory over Gonzaga File:ButlerGonzaga2013 06.JPG|ESPN personalities on scene for College Gameday ==Panorama== {{wide image|ButlerGonzaga2013 17.jpg|1000px|A panorama prior to the start of the [[2012–13 Butler Bulldogs men's basketball team|Butler]]-[[2012–13 Gonzaga Bulldogs men's basketball team|Gonzaga]] game, Saturday, January 19, 2013.}} {{wide image|Hinkle panorama inside.JPG|1000px|A panorama of the interior of Hinkle Fieldhouse, taken during the first half of a basketball game between the [[2007–08 Butler Bulldogs men's basketball team|Butler Bulldogs]] and the [[Green Bay Phoenix men's basketball|Green Bay Phoenix]].}} ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Hinkle Fieldhouse}} *[http://www.nps.gov/nr/travel/indianapolis/butlerfieldhouse.htm Butler Fieldhouse from Indianapolis, a National Park Service ''Discover Our Shared Heritage'' Travel Itinerary] {{Butler University}} {{Butler Bulldogs men's basketball navbox}} {{Big East Conference basketball venue navbox}} {{Indiana NCAA Division I college {{Infobox Basketball club | color1 =#FFFFFF | color2 =#0099FF | name =KK AMAK SP | logo = | nickname = | imagesize = | leagues= | founded =2005 | dissolved = 2009 | history ='''KK AMAK SP'''
(2005–2009) | arena =[[Biljanini Izvori hall]] | location =[[Ohrid]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] | colors = | president = | coach = | website = | championships = '''1''' [[Macedonian Basketball Cup|Macedonian Cup]] | h_body=0099FF|h_pattern_b=|h_shorts=ffffff|h_pattern_s= | a_body=FFFFFF|a_pattern_b=|a_shorts=0099FF|a_pattern_s= }} '''KK AMAK SP''' was a [[basketball]] club from [[Ohrid]], [[Republic of Macedonia]]. AMAK SP participated in the [[Macedonian Premier League (basketball)|Macedonian Premier League]]. Their home arena was the [[Biljanini Izvori hall]]. ==History== AMAK SP was formed in the year 2005 in the city of Ohrid by the AMAK SP a safety belts producing company. They have been playing the Second Macedonian League but as of the 2006 season they advanced to the Macedonian First League. In 2009, the club won its first major trophy by winning the Macedonian Basketball Cup. ==Honours== ===Domestic Achievements=== *[[Macedonian Basketball Cup|Macedonian Cup Winner]] - 2009 ==Notable players== :'''To appear in this section, a player must have either:''' * Played at least one full season for the club. * Set a club record or won an individual award while at the club. * Played at least one official international match for their national team at any time. * To perform very successfully during period in the club or at later/previous stages of his career. {{col-begin}} {{col-4}} *{{flagicon|MKD}} [[Eftim Bogoev]] *{{flagicon|MKD}} [[Vojdan Stojanovski]] *{{flagicon|MKD}} [[Damjan Stojanovski]] *{{flagicon|MKD}} [[Igor Penov]] *{{flagicon|MKD}} [[Vlatko Nedelkov]] *{{flagicon|MKD}} [[Angel Tasevski]] *{{flagicon|MKD}} [[Igor Trajkovski]] {{col-4}} *{{flagicon|USA}} [[Jarrid Frye]] *{{flagicon|USA}} [[Will Caudle]] *{{flagicon|SRB}} [[Mirolsav Čubrilo]] *{{flagicon|SRB}} [[Slaviša Bogavac]] *{{flagicon|SRB}} [[Slobodan Agoč]] *{{flagicon|SRB}} [[Ninoslav Tmušić]] *{{flagicon|BIH}} [[Mladen Gambiroža]] {{col-4}} {{col-end}} ==References== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080319053557/http://www.kkamak.org.mk/ KK AMAK SP Official Web site] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071026064721/http://basketball.org.mk/klub.asp?id=8 KK AMAK SP profile on Basketball.org.mk] {{DEFAULTSORT:Amak Sp}} [[Category:Basketball teams in the Republic of Macedonia]] [[Category:Sport in Ohrid]] {{RMacedonia-basketball-team-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = KV Arena | image = Kvarena-2.jpg | image_size = 225px | location = [[Karlovy Vary]], [[Czech Republic]] | opened = {{Start date|df=yes|2009|06|19}} | owner = KV Arena, s.r.o. | construction_cost = 1.5 billion CZK | tenants = [[HC Energie Karlovy Vary]] | seating_capacity = 6,000 (Multi-purpose Hall)
800 (Ball Sports Hall) }} '''KV Arena''' is an [[indoor arena|indoor sporting arena]] located in [[Karlovy Vary]], [[Czech Republic]]. The capacity of the arena is 6,000 people and was built in 2009. It is currently home to the [[HC Energie Karlovy Vary]] [[ice hockey]] team. KV Arena comprises 4 interconnecting halls: Multi-purpose Hall (Main Hall), Training Hall, Ball Sports Hall and Swimming Pool. ==External links== *[http://kvarena.cz/ Official site] {{coord|50|13|28|N|12|50|40|E|type:landmark_region:CZ|display=t}} [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in the Czech Republic]] [[Category:Sport in Karlovy Vary]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in the Karlovy Vary Region]] [[Category:2009 establishments in the Czech Republic]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2009]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=November 2009}} [[File:WikiLando.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Los Angeles Galaxy]] star [[Landon Donovan]] joined English [[Premier League]] club [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on loan from January 2010 until the start of the [[2010 Major League Soccer season|2010 MLS season]].]] In [[sport]]s, a '''loan''' involves a particular player being able to temporarily play for a club other than the one he is currently contracted to. Loan deals may last from a few weeks to all season-long and can persist for multiple seasons.
Players may be loaned out to other clubs for several reasons. Most commonly, young [[Prospect (sports)|prospects]] will be loaned to a club in a lower league in order to gain valuable [[first team]] experience. In this instance, the parent club may continue to pay the player's wages in full or in part. Some clubs put a formal arrangement in place with a [[Farm team|feeder club]] for this purpose, such as [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] and [[Royal Antwerp FC|Royal Antwerp]],<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.thenational.ae/sport/football/antwerp-connection-is-a-belgium-delight-for-manchester-united |title= Antwerp connection is a Belgium delight for Manchester United |last= Mitten |first= Andy |date= 9 March 2012 |website= thenational.ae |publisher= [[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]] |accessdate= 22 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2332561/Former-Chelsea-striker-Jimmy-Floyd-Hasselbaink-new-coach-Manchester-Uniteds-partner-club-Royal-Antwerp.html |title= Former Chelsea hitman Hasselbaink takes over as coach at Manchester United's partner club Royal Antwerp |last= Skillen |first= Charlie |date= 29 May 2013 |website= dailymail.co.uk |publisher= [[The Daily Mail]] |accessdate= 22 December 2014}}</ref> [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] and [[K.S.K. Beveren|Beveren]],<ref>{{cite news | last = Jones | first = Meirion | title = Arsenal face Fifa investigation | publisher = BBC News | date = 2006-06-27 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/newsnight/5037494.stm | accessdate = 2008-06-10 }}</ref> or [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] and [[Vitesse Arnhem|Vitesse]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://weaintgotnohistory.sbnation.com/2013/11/13/5098996/chelsea-fc-vitesse-arnhem-relationship |title= Fortifying an Empire: The Chelsea-Vitesse Partnership |last= Cohen |first= Jake |date= 13 November 2013 |website= weaintgotnohistory.com |publisher= [[SB Nation]] |accessdate= 22 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/how-vitesse-became-chelseas-finishing-school |title= How Vitesse became Chelsea's finishing school |last= Born |first= Elko |date= 10 January 2014 |website= fourfourtwo.com |publisher= [[FourFourTwo]] |accessdate= 22 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/apr/01/chelsea-vitesse-arnhem-roman-abramovich |title= Chelsea and Vitesse Arnhem' links investigated by the Dutch FA |last= Fifield |first= Dominic |date= 1 April 2014 |website= theguardian.com |publisher= The Guardian |accessdate= 22 December 2014}}</ref> In other leagues such as Italy's [[Serie A]], some smaller clubs have a reputation as a "farm club" and regularly take players, especially younger players, on loan from larger clubs.
A club may take a player on loan if they are short on transfer funds but can still pay wages, or as temporary cover for injuries or suspensions. The parent club might demand a fee or that the loaning club pays some or all of the player's wages during the loan period.<ref>{{cite web | last = Marsh | first = Jaymes | title = Football Transfers Explained | publisher = Tottenham Hotspur Blog News | date = 2007-06-07 | url = http://tottenhamhotspur.blogspot.com/2007/06/football-transfers-explained.html | accessdate = 2008-06-10 }}</ref> A club might seek to loan out a squad player to make a saving on his wages, or a first team player to regain match fitness following an injury.
A loan may be made to get around a [[transfer window]]. Such a loan might include an agreed fee for a permanent transfer when the next transfer window opens.
Some players are loaned because they are unhappy or in dispute with their current club and no other club wishes to buy them permanently. Examples of this situation include [[Henri Camara]] with [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]], [[Craig Bellamy]] with [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], and [[Darren Bent]] with [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]].
In the [[Premier League]], players on loan are not permitted to play against the team which holds their registration (section 7.2 of rule M.6). Loanees are, however, allowed to play against their 'owning' clubs in cup competitions, unless they have played for their owning club in that cup during that season.
==Unpaid trialists==
In the [[Scottish Professional Football League]] (and previously the [[Scottish Football League]]), clubs are permitted to take players on as unpaid trialists even for competitive fixtures. Sometimes for the first two weeks of a trial period players' names are obfuscated; match reports use the convention "A Trialist" to refer to such players in lieu of using their real names.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.spfl.co.uk/docs/067_324__therulesofthespfl_1375800603.pdf |title=The Rules of the Scottish Professional Football League |page=112}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Free transfer (association football)|Free transfer]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Loan (Sports)}} [[Category:Terminology used in multiple sports]] [[Category:Association football terminology]] [[Category:Rugby league terminology]] [[Category:Rugby union terminology]] [[Category:Loans]] [[Category:Sports labor relations]]

San José | clubs2 = [[C.D. Platense Municipal Zacatecoluca|Platense]] | clubs3 = [[C.D. FAS|FAS]] | clubs4 = [[C.D. Águila|Águila]] | clubs5 = [[C.D. Chalatenango|Chalatenango]] | clubs6 = [[Alianza F.C.|Alianza]] | clubs7 = [[C.D. Universidad de El Salvador|UES]]<ref>http://www.laprensagrafica.com/deportes/futbol-nacional/193548-ues-es-prioridad-para-luis-anaya</ref> | clubs8 = [[C.D. Águila|Águila]] | caps1 = | caps2 = | caps3 = | caps4 = 28 | caps5 = 26 | caps6 = 30 | caps7 = | caps8 = 76<ref>http://www.ceroacero.es/player.php?id=71556</ref> | goals1 = | goals2 = | goals3 = | goals4 = 0 | goals5 = 0 | goals6 = 1 | goals7 = | goals8 = 2 | nationalyears1 = 2006–2011 | nationalteam1 = [[El Salvador national football team|El Salvador]] | nationalcaps1 = 37 | nationalgoals1 = 4 | pcupdate = April 6, 2017 | ntupdate = April 6, 2017 }}
{{spanish name 2|Anaya|Merino}} '''Luis Alonso Anaya Merino''' (Born May 19, 1981, in [[San José Guayabal]], [[El Salvador]]) is a former Salvadoran professional [[Association football|football]] player.
==Club career== Anaya started his senior career at local side San José, before moving to [[Segunda División de Fútbol Salvadoreño|Salvadoran Second Division]] side [[C.D. Platense Municipal Zacatecoluca|Platense]] where he stayed for almost 8 years.
In May 2005, he made his debut on the [[Salvadoran Primera División|highest domestic level]] for Salvadoran giants [[C.D. FAS|FAS]] against [[C.D. Águila|Águila]],<ref>[http://www.clubdeportivofas.com/Plantillas/Fichas/03_Luis_Anaya.html Player profile] - CD FAS {{es icon}}</ref> whom he joined after winning the 2005 Clausura title with [[CD FAS|FAS]] a month after that debut.
In 2008, he signed with [[C.D. Chalatenango|Chalatenango]], only to move on to [[Alianza F.C.|Alianza]] in the same year.
He joined [[C.D. UES|CD UES]] for the 2010 Apertura season.
==International career== Anaya officially received his first cap on October 7, 2006, in a friendly match against [[Panama national football team|Panama]].
He scored his first goal for the national team on August 22, 2007, in a friendly match against [[Honduras national football team|Honduras]].
His second, and most important goal came almost a year later on June 22, 2008, in a [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification - CONCACAF Second Round|FIFA World Cup qualification]] match against [[Panama national football team|Panama]].
His 87th-minute goal, led El Salvador to a 3–1 win, and in doing so helped secured the national team a spot in the following round of qualification.
He has earned a total of 35 caps, scoring 2 goals. He has represented his country in 8 [[FIFA World Cup qualification]] matches<ref>{{FIFA player|276786|Luis Anaya}} </ref> and played at the [[2007 UNCAF Nations Cup]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesg/gold-cam07det.html| title=UNCAF (Qualifying Tournament for Gold Cup) 2007 - Details| dead-url=no| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081024034751/http://www.rsssf.com/tablesg/gold-cam07det.html |archivedate=2008-10-24| publisher=RSSSF}}</ref> He also was a non-playing squad member at the [[2007 CONCACAF Gold Cup]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.rsssf.com/tables/07gc-full.html#squads| title=CONCACAF Championship, Gold Cup 2007 - Full Details| dead-url=no| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081024002319/http://www.rsssf.com/tables/07gc-full.html |archivedate=2008-10-24| publisher=RSSSF}}</ref>
He did not play for his country since an October 2008 [[FIFA World Cup qualification]] match against [[Suriname national football team|Suriname]] and was only over two years later called up for the [[2011 Copa Centroamericana]] by then coach [[José Luis Rugamas]].
With [[Rubén Israel]] as coach, Anaya was called up to take part at the [[2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup]] where he earned 4 caps in 4 games.
Anaya received two yellow cards at the semi-finals match against [[Panama national football team|Panama]] for complaining.
In a frinedly match against [[Venezuela national football team|Venezuela]], on 7 August 2011, Anaya was sent off with two yellow cards, because he complained and celebrated in front of the technical area of the Venezuelans.
On September 20, 2013, Anaya was one of 14 Salvadoran players banned for life due to their involvement with match fixing.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-24184567 |title= El Salvador match-fixing: 14 footballers banned for life |publisher= BBC |accessdate=21 September 2013}}</ref>
===International goals=== {| class="wikitable" ! # !! Date !! Venue !! Opponent !! Score !! Result !! Competition |- | 1 || 22 August 2007 || [[Estadio Cuscatlán]], [[San Salvador]], [[El Salvador]] || {{fb|HON}} || '''1'''–0 || 2–0 || [[Friendly match]] |- | 2 || 22 June 2008 || [[Estadio Cuscatlán]], [[San Salvador]], [[El Salvador]] || {{fb|PAN}} || '''3'''–1 || 3–1 || [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification]] |- | 3 || 6 September 2011 || [[Truman Bodden Stadium]], [[George Town, Cayman Islands|George Town]], [[Cayman Islands]] || {{fb|CAY}} || 1–'''2''' || 1–4 || [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification]] |- | 4 || 6 September 2011 || [[Truman Bodden Stadium]], [[George Town, Cayman Islands|George Town]], [[Cayman Islands]] || {{fb|CAY}} || 1–'''3''' || 1–4 || [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification]] |}

page.title: Never Miss a Super Bowl Club

revision.comment: link [[Super Bowl LII]] using [[:en:User:Edward/Find link|Find link]]
revision.text:
The '''Never Miss a Super Bowl Club''' (or the '''NMASB Club''') is a group of people that was popularized in a [[Visa Inc.|Visa]] commercial in 2010. They have attended every [[Super Bowl]] since 1967.<ref name=WTSP>{{cite web|title="Never Miss a Super Bowl Club" turns 44|url=http://www.wtsp.com/news/mostpop/story.aspx?storyid=124639&provider=top|publisher=[[WTSP]]|accessdate=6 February 2011|date=February 2010}}</ref> As shown on the commercial, the group consisted of four people, although it was announced in February 2011 that one member would not be able to attend that year's game.
==Background== The club was first popularized by [[Visa Inc.|Visa]] as part of an advertising campaign called ''Go Fans''. The commercial was narrated by [[Morgan Freeman]]. Surveys have shown that most respondents would be willing to miss or postpone major events in their life, including the birth of their child or a wedding date, to see the [[Super Bowl]]. As a result, Visa came up with an advertising campaign to feature four men who have attended every Super Bowl since the first one in 1967.<ref name=Visa>{{cite web|title=Visa Features Four Fans who Attended Every Super Bowl in New Ads as Part of the Super Bowl Trip for Life: Passion for Super Bowl is Unrivaled According to a National Survey by Visa|url=http://corporate.visa.com/media-center/press-releases/press1062.jsp|publisher=[[Visa Inc.|Visa]]|accessdate=6 February 2011|date=October 14, 2010}}</ref> The four men were [[New England Patriots]] fan Don Crisman, [[San Francisco 49ers]] fan Larry Jacobson, [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] fan Thomas Henschel, and [[Green Bay Packers]] fan Robert Cook. The commercial itself featured the four men holding up tickets for 44 years of Super Bowls. At one point, there were five members, but one became immobile after turning 80.<ref name=WSAW>{{cite web|title=Group of Friends Has Never Missed Superbowl (sic)|url=http://www.wsaw.com/home/headlines/83632877.html|publisher=[[WSAW]]|accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> In 2017, another person who had also gone to every Super Bowl game, Gregory Eaton, met the three remaining members and officially joined the club.<ref>http://www.startribune.com/three-men-52-years-and-a-vow-to-always-be-at-the-super-bowl/472267413/</ref>
==Promotion== A promotion was also run during the commercial. ''The Super Bowl Trip for Life Sweepstakes'' stated that anyone who used their Visa card between September 9 and December 31, 2010, would be entered to win a chance to see the Super Bowl for life. Winners would receive round-trip airfare, accommodations, and tickets to the Super Bowl.<ref name=Visa /> In 2011, it was announced that Tyler Weber, then 24 years old, won the contest.<ref>{{cite web|last=Blaisdell|first=Elaine|title=LaVale man winner of Visa’s Super Bowl for Life contest|url=http://times-news.com/local/x1527122165/LaVale-man-winner-of-Visa-s-Super-Bowl-for-Life-contest|work=Cumberland Times-News|accessdate=7 April 2013}}</ref>
==Loss of a member== In early February 2011, it was announced that 79-year-old Robert Cook would be unable to attend [[Super Bowl XLV]] after being hospitalized in [[Wisconsin]]. His daughters were expected to attend the game in his place.<ref name=Latimes>{{cite news|title=1 in 'Never Missed a Super Bowl' club hospitalized, will miss game with his beloved Packers|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/football/nfl/wire/sns-ap-fbn-super-bowl-never-missed,0,2482719.story |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=5 February 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Cook in hospital, unable to attend game|url=http://msn.foxsports.com/nfl/story/never-miss-a-super-bowl-club-member-in-hospital-020511|publisher=Fox Sports|accessdate=6 February 2011|date=February 5, 2011}}</ref> He died a few days later.<ref>{{cite web|title='Never missed a Super Bowl' member passes away|url=http://msn.foxsports.com/nfl/story/Never-Missed-Super-Bowl-Club-member-dies-021411?GT1=39002|publisher=Fox Sports|accessdate=14 February 2011|date=February 14, 2011}}</ref> The remaining three members of the club have continued their tradition through at least [[Super Bowl LI]].
In October 2017, member Larry Jacobson, 78, of San Francisco, CA passed away. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/sfgate/obituary.aspx?n=lawrence-jacobson&pid=187109526|title=Lawrence Jacobson's Obituary on San Francisco Chronicle|website=San Francisco Chronicle|access-date=2017-11-22}}</ref>
==New members== On [[Super Bowl LII]] a new member Gregory Eaton joined the club to bring it back to 3 members. Also joined is honorary member Heather Jacobson,the daughter of Larry Jacobson,who was one of the original 4 members
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Super Bowl commercials}}
[[Category:Super Bowl advertising]] [[Category:Sports organisations established in 1967]] [[Category:Sports fandom]]

[[File:Harry Grove Scoreboard.jpg|border|300px]] | caption = The Harry Grove Stadium scoreboard in August 2009 | former name = | location = 21 Stadium Drive
[[Frederick, Maryland]] 21703 | coordinates = {{coord|39|24|05|N|77|24|48|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = July 23, 1989{{cite news |title=Keys Slideshow|url=http://www.fredericknewspost.com/media/slideshows/keys0206/keys.html|newspaper=[[Frederick News-Post]]|date=February 6, 2009|accessdate=September 22, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207142614/http://www.fredericknewspost.com/media/slideshows/keys0206/keys.html|archivedate=February 7, 2009}} | built = | opened = April 19, 1990 | renovated = 2005, 2006, 2008 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Frederick, Maryland|City of Frederick]] | operator = [[Frederick Keys|Maryland Baseball Holding LLC]] | surface = Grass | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]7 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|7000000|1990}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = [[Ellerbe Becket]]{{cite news |title=Major Firms Playing in the Minors Too|first=Jeff|last=Ostrowski|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/1999/07/19990726/No-Topic-Name/Major-Firms-Playing-In-The-Minors-Too.aspx|work=SportsBusiness Journal|date=July 26, 1999|accessdate=November 8, 2011}} | structural engineer = [[Walter P Moore Engineers and Consultants|Harper & Kerr, P. A.]]{{cite web |title=Request for Proposals Homestead Baseball Stadium Complex|url=http://local.cityofhomestead.com/WebLink8/0/doc/32985/Page15.aspx|publisher=City of Homestead|date=May 5, 1989|accessdate=August 11, 2013|page=15}} | project_manager = [[Opening Day Partners]] | general_contractor = Morgan-Keller Inc.{{cite news |title=News in Brief|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1991-08-19/business/1991231091_1_ad-categories-awards-competition-design|newspaper=[[The Baltimore Sun]]|date=August 19, 1991|accessdate=March 3, 2012}} | tenants = [[Frederick Keys]] ([[Carolina League|CL]]) (1990–present) | seating_capacity = 5,400{{cite web |title=Fan Guide|url=http://www.milb.com/team1/page.jsp?ymd=20100223&content_id=8118166&vkey=team1_t493&fext=.jsp&sid=t493|publisher=Minor League Baseball|date=February 23, 2010|accessdate=February 24, 2014}} | record_attendance = 11,006 on August 30, 1997{{cite news |title=Morris Is A Crowd Pleaser|first=Stan|last=Goldberg|url=http://www.fredericknewspost.com/archives/article_d77e9930-f656-58bb-94b0-a59c39678ce0.html|newspaper=[[Frederick News-Post]]|date=August 25, 2001|accessdate=February 24, 2014}} | dimensions = Left Field: 325 feet
Center Field: 400 feet
Right Field: 325 feet }} '''Nymeo Field at Harry Grove Stadium''', located in [[Frederick, Maryland]], is the home of the [[Frederick Keys]], a class A minor league affiliate of the [[Baltimore Orioles]]. Opened in 1990, it seats 5,400 fans. ==History== [[File:Harry Grove Stadium.jpg|thumb|left|Harry Grove Stadium in August 2009.]] The stadium is named for Harry Grove, who was one of the founders of the Frederick Hustlers, a professional team that existed between 1915 and the [[World War II]] era. The Grove family also donated $250,000 to the city to help build the park and were thus honored in the naming of it. Another $1 million was provided by the city of Frederick along with $1.5 million provided by the state of Maryland and $250,000 from [[Frederick County, Maryland|Frederick County]].{{cite news |title=The Boys of Summers Past; Cherished Memories Resurface as Baseball Returns to Frederick|first=Paul|last=Duggan|url=http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=732069082&sid=1&Fmt=2&clientId=4807&RQT=309&VName=HNP|format=[[PDF]]|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=January 12, 1989|accessdate=January 7, 2007}} The 2005 Class A all-star game, pitting the [[Carolina League]] against the [[California League]], was played in Harry Grove Stadium.{{cite news |title=Frederick to Be Star-Struck|first=Stan|last=Goldberg|url=http://www.fredericknewspost.com/archives/frederick-to-be-star-struck/article_892754b1-94dc-5b1d-97db-ff37697b8e37.html|newspaper=[[Frederick News-Post]]|date=June 28, 2005|accessdate=May 30, 2014}} Harry Grove Stadium has also hosted various concerts. On August 19, 2006, [[Bob Dylan]] played to a sell-out crowd during his third annual 'Summer Minor League Baseball Park Tour'.{{cite news |title=Knockin' on Frederick's Door|first=Katie E.|last=Leslie|url=http://www.fredericknewspost.com/archives/article_c693fadc-911a-52ed-b4b3-65e232cba878.html?mode=jqm|newspaper=[[Frederick News-Post]]|date=August 20, 2006|accessdate=February 24, 2014}} The [[World Wrestling Entertainment]] (WWE) has made it an annual summer stop on its live event tours, a rarity in that the stadium is an outdoor venue. Harry Grove Stadium also serves host to several autocross clubs, who use the lower lot for their autocross course. ==Renovations== In 2006, Keys ownership began a project to revitalize Harry Grove Stadium. Renovations have included a new field, seating section, suite level restoration and a new lighting system.{{cite news |title=Keys' Stadium Getting New Playing Field|first=Joseph M.|last=deLeon|url=http://www.fredericknewspost.com/archives/article_131f3e41-492d-52f1-986c-5a7d4e20a3c1.html?mode=jqm|newspaper=[[Frederick News-Post]]|date=September 20, 2006|accessdate=May 30, 2014}} A new [[state-of-the-art]] scoreboard and videoboard and brand new audio visual equipment was in place for the 2009 season. The scoreboard has an all new [[LED]] technology speed of pitch, clock and full color high resolution LED message center. The State-of-the-Art videoboard is 50% larger than its predecessor and supports high definition video input for a cleaner, crisper image.{{cite news |title=A Few Key Improvements to Harry Grove Stadium|first=Kristina|last=Negas|url=http://www.fredericknewspost.com/archive/article_bdf4388a-651b-55b7-b0c6-9d87872fd89a.html?mode=jqm|newspaper=[[Frederick News-Post]]|date=April 10, 2009|accessdate=May 30, 2014}} Further upgrades include public restrooms that have been completely renovated along with those in the clubhouse, and multiple improvements to bring Harry Grove Stadium into compliance with the [[Americans with Disabilities Act]].{{cite news |title=New Scoreboard, Video Screen Approved for Grove Stadium|first=Adam|last=Behsudi|url=http://www.fredericknewspost.com/archive/new-scoreboard-video-screen-approved-for-grove-stadium-slide-show/article_4d38cb9f-c6a6-5ff5-b146-c428856b76a5.html|newspaper=[[Frederick News-Post]]|date=February 6, 2009|accessdate=February 24, 2014}} ==Naming Rights== On December 5, 2013, the Frederick Mayor and Board of Aldermen approved an amended contract that will allow the Frederick Keys to seek a sponsor for stadium naming rights while retaining "Harry Grove" as part of the name.{{cite news |title=Frederick City Approves Naming Rights for Harry Grove Stadium Complex|first=Jen|last=Bondeson|url=http://www.fredericknewspost.com/news/politics_and_government/levels_of_government/city_of_frederick/article_6076ccce-9800-5b3f-aa40-1842b7986a1c.html|newspaper=[[Frederick News-Post]]|date=December 6, 2013|accessdate=December 8, 2013}}{{cite news |title=Frederick Approves Sale of Naming Rights for Keys Stadium|url=http://www.heraldmailmedia.com/news/local/frederick-approves-sale-of-naming-rights-for-keys-stadium/article_7d57ef16-5ed7-11e3-9e9a-0019bb30f31a.html|newspaper=[[The Herald-Mail]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|location=[[Hagerstown, Maryland]]|date=December 6, 2013|accessdate=December 8, 2013}} Mayor Randy McClement said, "The stadium is always going to be Harry Grove Stadium. But the idea behind naming rights is to look at portions of the stadium that could used for naming rights."{{cite news |title=Frederick City Aldermen Address Fund Balance Shortfall|url=http://www.wfmd.com/pages/localnews2.html?feed=119935&article=11888269|work=[[WFMD]]|date=December 6, 2013|accessdate=December 8, 2013}} The city will get 35% of the net profit from the naming fees with the remainder going to the team. On February 5, 2015, the Frederick Keys announced a deal had been reached with Nymeo Federal Credit Union to use the name "Nymeo Field at Harry Grove Stadium."{{cite news |title=Keys Announce Naming Rights Partnership with Nymeo Federal Credit Union|url=http://www.milb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20150205&content_id=108459808&fext=.jsp&vkey=news_t493&sid=t493|work=[[Frederick Keys]]|date=February 5, 2015|accessdate=February 5, 2015}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.milb.com/team1/page.jsp?ymd=20100223&content_id=8118166&vkey=team1_t493&fext=.jsp&sid=t493 Frederick Keys - Harry Grove Stadium] *[http://www.littleballparks.com/Stadium/2001/Frederick/Fred.htm Harry Grove Stadium Views - ''Ball Parks of the Minor Leagues''] {{Carolina League ballparks}} [[Category:1990 establishments in Maryland]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1990]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Maryland]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Frederick County, Maryland]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Frederick County, Maryland]] [[Category:Sports in Frederick, Maryland]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Oestrike Stadium | nickname = | image = EMU baseball stands.JPG | location = [[Ypsilanti, Michigan]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = | opened = 1971 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Eastern Michigan University]] | operator = Eastern Michigan University | surface = Astro Turf | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | project_manager = | former_names = | tenants = [[Eastern Michigan Eagles#Baseball|Eastern Michigan Eagles baseball]] ([[Mid-American Conference|MAC]]) (1971-present)
[[Oakland County Cruisers|Midwest Sliders of Ypsilanti/ Oakland County Cruisers]] ([[Frontier League]]) (2009-2010) | seating_capacity = 2,500 | record_attendance = | dimensions = }} '''Oestrike Stadium''' is a [[stadium]] in [[Ypsilanti, Michigan]] at [[Eastern Michigan University]]. It is named after [[Ron Oestrike]], a former baseball coach at EMU. It is primarily used for [[baseball]], and serves as the [[Eastern Michigan University]] Eagles baseball team home field. In addition, it served as the home field of the [[Oakland County Cruisers|Midwest Sliders of Ypsilanti]] [[Frontier League]] baseball team in 2009 and 2010 (the Sliders were renamed the Oakland County Cruisers their second season at Oestrike Stadium as a result of their planned move to [[Waterford Township, Michigan|Waterford Township]]). Several present and former major leaguers, including [[Bob Welch (baseball)|Bob Welch]], [[Bob Owchinko]], [[Bryan Clutterbuck]], [[Pat Sheridan]], and [[Brian Bixler]], played at Oestrike Stadium as members of the EMU baseball team. ==History== [[File:EMU baseball stadium.JPG|thumb|250px|left|Oestrike Stadium]] Constructed in 1971, Oestrike Stadium is named affer Ronald E. Oestrike. Ronald "Oak" Oestrike was a former Baseball Coach.{{cite web |url=http://www.emich.edu/focus_emu/021009/athleticclubhof.html |work=Focus EMU Online |title=Five to be inducted into E-Club Athletic Hall of Fame |publisher=Eastern Michigan University |date=2009-02-10 |accessdate=2011-06-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605201007/http://www.emich.edu/focus_emu//021009/athleticclubhof.html |archivedate=2010-06-05 |df= }} Oestrike served as a head baseball coach from 1965 to 87. Oestrike Statium has 2,500 seats for baseball and softball events. It hosted the Mid- American Conference Baseball Tournament in 2007. In 2008, [[Bruce Springsteen]] performed at Oestrike Stadium in support of [[Barack Obama]] during his presidential candidacy. The stadium has gone through several renovations to update cosmetic needs.{{cite web |url=http://merlyn.emich.edu/library/about/archives/campusbuilding.php?building_id=39 |title=Oestrike Stadium |publisher=Eastern Michigan University |date= |accessdate=2011-06-14 }}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Oestrike stadium is located near Westview Apartments and [[Rynearson Stadium]] ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.emueagles.com/Sports/gen/2008/OestrikeStadiumInformation.asp Ballpark information] * [http://www.freep.com/article/20081010/SPORTS21/810100405/1217/SPORTS Article about Cruisers playing at ballpark] {{coord|42.257809|-83.648079|type:landmark|display=title}} {{Eastern Michigan University}} {{Mid-American Conference baseball venue navbox}} {{Michigan NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} [[Category:Sports venues in Michigan]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1971]] [[Category:Eastern Michigan Eagles baseball]] [[Category:1971 establishments in Michigan]] {{Michigan-baseball-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=July 2013}} [[Image:Darren Gough bowling.jpg|thumb|left|200px|English cricketer [[Darren Gough]] about to deliver the ball overarm-style.]] {{Cricket deliveries}} In [[cricket]], '''overarm bowling''' refers to a delivery in which the bowler's hand is above shoulder height.
When cricket originated all bowlers delivered the ball [[underarm bowling|underarm]], where the bowler's hand is below waist height. However, so the story goes, John Willes became the first bowler to use a "round-arm" technique after practising with his sister Christine Willes, who had used the technique, as she was unable to bowl underarm due to her wide and huge skirt impeding her delivery of the ball.<ref>http://www.cricketweb.net/resources/history/index.php John Willes and his sister invent overarm bowling</ref>
A [[roundarm bowling|roundarm]] delivery is where the hand is between shoulder height and waist height;
After roundarm was legalised in 1835 with the bowler allowed to deliver the ball at shoulder height, it was not long before some bowlers began to raise the hand above the shoulder. The [[Laws of Cricket]] at that time directed that such a delivery be called a [[no-ball]]. In 1845, the law was strengthened by removing the benefit of doubt from the bowler in height of hand questions, the umpire's view of the incident being final.
Even so, it was only a matter of time before confrontation occurred. The problem was that many umpires were themselves bowlers and believed that the bowler should be allowed to bowl with a fully raised hand. The watershed was reached on 26 August 1862 at [[The Oval]] when Surrey hosted All-England. The England bowler [[Edgar Willsher]] deliberately bowled overarm and was no-balled six times in succession by umpire [[John Lillywhite]], ironically the son of [[William Lillywhite]], the famous bowler who had done so much to have roundarm legalised in 1835.
In what was surely a pre-rehearsed demonstration, Willsher and the other eight professionals in the England team staged a walk-off, leaving their two amateur colleagues looking non-plussed in the middle. Play continued next day, but Lillywhite diplomatically withdrew and was replaced by another umpire.
[[Marylebone Cricket Club|MCC]] responded to this "crisis" with rather more haste than they had to roundarm and changed the Laws of Cricket in time for the 1864 season. Law 10 was rewritten to allow the bowler to bring his arm through at any height providing he kept it straight and did not throw the ball. This completed the evolution of bowling and the overarm style has remained predominant ever since, though some conservatives (including [[W G Grace]], no less) did continue to bowl roundarm till the end of their careers; and even underarm itself was still seen occasionally.
An interesting historical development of the legalisation of overarm was that for many years, 1864 was deemed to mark the start of "first-class cricket" which suggested that earlier cricket was "second-class". The 1864 origin has been strongly challenged: ''see also'' [[First-class cricket]].
==References== <references/>
==External sources== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100220005023/http://www.lords.org/laws-and-spirit/laws-of-cricket Laws of cricket] * [http://www.cricinfo.com/ci/content/story/248600.html The evolution of bowling]
==Further reading== * [[Arthur Haygarth]], ''Scores & Biographies, Volume 7 (1861-1862)'', Lillywhite, 1863 * [[Arthur Haygarth]], ''Scores & Biographies, Volume 8 (1863-1864)'', Lillywhite, 1865 * [[Harry Altham|H S Altham]], ''A History of Cricket, Volume 1 (to 1914)'', George Allen & Unwin, 1962 * [[Derek Birley]], ''A Social History of English Cricket'', Aurum, 1999 * [[Rowland Bowen]], ''Cricket: A History of its Growth and Development'', Eyre & Spottiswoode, 1970 * [[John Major]], ''More Than A Game'', HarperCollins, 2007
[[Category:Cricket terminology]] [[Category:Bowling (cricket)]]

/* Rawlings and Major League Baseball */ owners
revision.text:
{{Primary sources|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox company | name = Rawlings | logo = Rawlings sports equipment (logo).png | logo_size = 150px | type = Private | foundation = [[St. Louis, Missouri]] (1887) | location_city = [[Town and Country, Missouri]] | location_country = USA | key_people = | industry = | products = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = 1,200 globally
(150 in St. Louis) | parent = [[Major League Baseball Properties]] and Seidler Equity Partners | homepage = [http://www.rawlings.com www.rawlings.com] }} '''Rawlings''' is a sports equipment manufacturing company based in [[Town and Country, Missouri]] and founded in 1887. The parent company has been [[Newell Brands]] since 2016. Rawlings specializes in baseball equipment, but also manufactures softball, basketball, training equipment and American footballs. They have also recently started making fan gear such as chairs, tents, and bags with team logos on them. The [[Horween Leather Company]] has provided Rawlings with leather since 1929.{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/768252861.html?dids=768252861:768252861&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Dec+19%2C+2004&author=William+Hageman&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=Take+him+back+to+the+ball+game&pqatl=google |author= William Hageman |title=Take him back to the ball game |work=Chicago Tribune |date=December 19, 2004 |accessdate=March 26, 2013}} In 2003, Horween was providing leather for 3,000 Rawlings [[baseball glove]]s annually, and half of professional baseball players were using baseball gloves made from Horween leather.{{cite news|author = Barbara Rolek|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2003-10-27/business/0310270217_1_bob-clevenhagen-rawlings-glove |title=Horween's leather bound by tradition |work=Chicago Tribune |date=October 27, 2003 |accessdate=October 3, 2015}} Rawlings is the most chosen glove of current Major League Baseball players.{{cite web |url=https://www.whatproswear.com/wpw-report-top-glove-brands-worn-by-mlb-stars/ |title=WPW Report: Top Glove Brands Worn by MLB Stars |work=What Pros Wear}} == History == Rawlings was founded in [[St. Louis|Saint Louis]] in 1887, during the middle of the [[Long Depression]], by George and Alfred Rawlings. The brothers set up a sporting goods store with its own catalog. They sold "Fishing Tackle, Guns, Baseball, Football, Golf, Polo, Tennis, Athletic and General Sporting Goods".[http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/rawlings-sporting-goods-co-inc-history/ Rawlings Sporting Goods Co., Inc. History]
The company was founded in 1887 by George and Alfred Rawlings, brothers who opened a small store in St. Louis. Its first catalogue characterized the company as "Dealers in Fishing Tackle, Guns, Baseball, Football, Golf, Polo, Tennis, Athletic and General Sporting Goods." The store soon went up in flames, so the Rawlings brothers got into manufacturing in 1898 in partnership with Charles W. Scudder, who put up the money. The company is credited with introducing football shoulder pads in 1902, and the first all-weather football. === Rawlings and Major League Baseball === Rawlings began providing the hometown [[St. Louis Cardinals]] with gloves in 1906. [[File:Paul Lo Duca.jpg|thumb|Here is Paul Lo Duca, a Washington Nationals player, wearing a Rawlings catcher mitt.]] In {{baseball year|1920}}, [[Bill Doak]], a pitcher for the [[St. Louis Cardinals]], suggested that a web be placed between the first finger and the thumb in order to create a pocket. This design soon became the standard for baseball gloves. Doak patented his design and sold it to Rawlings. His design became the precursor to modern gloves, and enabled Rawlings to become the preferred glove of professional players.{{cite web|last1=Stamp|first1=Jimmy|title=The Invention of the Baseball Mitt|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/arts-culture/the-invention-of-the-baseball-mitt-12799848/?no-ist|website=www.smithsonianmag.com|publisher=Smithsonian.com|accessdate=27 April 2015}} In 1955 [[Spalding (sports equipment)|Spalding]] bought Rawlings, and began using it to manufacture baseballs. In 1957 the company introduced the [[Gold Glove]] award, which became the major award for baseball. It also sponsors the [[Minor League Baseball]] (MiLB) "[[Rawlings Woman Executive of the Year]]" award. 13 years after acquiring it, an [[anti-trust]] investigation forced Spalding to sell Rawlings again, but as it did so Spalding set up a contract that would have Rawlings manufacture baseballs to sell with the Spalding logo. When this agreement ended in 1977, Rawlings began using its own logo, becoming the official supplier of the major leagues (producing separate balls for both the American and National Leagues from 1977 to 1999, and since 2000, a single ball for all of Major League Baseball), succeeding [[Spalding (sports equipment)|Spalding]], which had been the supplier for a century. All the balls supplied to the major and minor leagues are manufactured in Costa Rica.{{cite news|author = Leslie Josephs|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-costarica-baseballs-idUSTRE62831Z20100309 |title=Made in Costa Rica: U.S. Major League baseballs |work=Reuters |date=March 9, 2010 |accessdate=June 22, 2016}} Additional low-end versions are manufactured in China.{{cite news|author = Diane M. Grassi|url=http://www.renewamerica.com/columns/grassi/060725 |title=Baseball & Rawlings bring new meaning to free trade |work=RenewAmerica.com |date=July 25, 2006 |accessdate=June 22, 2016}} Many major leaguers have endorsed Rawlings equipment over the years. There are four main series for the gloves: the Gold Glove Series, the Heritage Pro Series, the Heart of the Hide Series, the Pro Preferred Series and the Gold Glove Collection Series. In 2003, [[K2 Sports|K2 Inc.]] acquired Rawlings.{{Cite web| last = Newsdesk| first = Associated Press| title = K2 Acquires Rawlings| work = Ski Mag| accessdate = 2018-11-25| url = https://www.skimag.com/uncategorized/k2-acquires-rawlings}} In 2005 Rawlings corporate headquarters were moved from [[Fenton, Missouri]], to [[Town and Country, Missouri]].{{cite news|author1=Unknown|title=Rawlings to move HQ to Maryville Centre|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/stlouis/stories/2005/08/15/daily24.html|accessdate=31 July 2014|work=St. Louis Business Times}} In 2007, [[Jarden]] acquired K2 Inc.{{Cite news| issn = 0458-3035| last = Reuters| first = From| title = Jarden to acquire K2 in $765-million deal| work = Los Angeles Times| accessdate = 2018-11-25| date = 2007-04-26| url = http://articles.latimes.com/2007/apr/26/business/fi-k226}} On December 14, 2015, [[Newell Rubbermaid]] announced that it would acquire Jarden for over $15 billion of cash and stock. The combined company was renamed Newell Brands.{{cite news|title=Newell Rubbermaid to Acquire Jarden for $15.4 Billion|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-12-14/newell-rubbermaid-to-buy-jarden-for-13-2-billion-adding-brands|accessdate=14 December 2015|work=Bloomberg}}{{cite news|title=Newell Rubbermaid to Buy Jarden for Over $15 Billion|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/newell-rubbermaid-and-jarden-strike-merger-deal-1450094318|accessdate=14 December 2015|work=The Wall Street Journal}} It was announced on June 5, 2018 that Rawlings was sold from Newell Brands to the [[Los Angeles]]-based [[private equity firm]], Seidler Equity Partners (SEP) (which owns [[LA Fitness]]), with MLB a co-investor in the $395 million deal. Rawlings employs 150 people in the St. Louis area, and 1,200 globally. The deal was completed on July 2, 2018.{{cite web |url=http://www.roi-nj.com/2018/07/02/industry/newell-wraps-up-sales-of-waddington-rawlings-units/ |title=Newell wraps up sales of Waddington, Rawlings units |work=ROINJ |date=July 2, 2018}} Rawlings previously made some custom baseball gloves at its plant in [[Washington, Missouri]], but no longer makes any baseball gloves in the United States, with the factory still open.{{cite web |url=http://www.stltoday.com/business/local/st-louis-county-based-rawlings-sold-to-group-that-includes/article_9695321a-a1e5-57ce-aeb9-72abe9fa19fa.html#tncms-source=infinity-scroll-summary-siderail-latest |title=St. Louis County-based Rawlings sold to group that includes Major League Baseball |work=[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]] |date=June 5, 2018}} ===Rawlings and NCAA baseball=== Rawlings currently sponsors numerous collegiate baseball teams in the [[NCAA]]. The flagship team for Rawlings is the [[Virginia Cavaliers baseball|Virginia Cavaliers]], winners of the [[2015 College World Series]]. ===Rawlings and American Legion Baseball=== Rawlings sponsors the Rawlings Big Stick Award, which is presented to the [[American Legion Baseball]] "player who accumulated the most total bases."[http://www.legion.org/baseball/awards Baseball Awards]. The American Legion Baseball official website. Retrieved 2009-11-21. ===Rawlings and National Football League=== As of August 19, 2010, Rawlings signed a multi year deal with the [[National Football League]] for products such as tent canopies, grills, and chairs. This will also include non-exclusive tailgate products such as coolers, stadium seats, and footballs.[http://sportsbusinessdigest.com/2010/08/sponsorship-news-nfl-and-rawlings-sign-deal/ "NFL and Rawlings sign deal"] ''Sports Business Digest'' ==Footnotes== {{reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category|Rawlings baseball equipment}} * [http://www.rawlings.com Rawlings corporate site] * [http://rawlings.com/GoldGlove.aspx Rawlings Gold Glove Award site.] * [http://www.rawlingsgear.com/ Rawlings Gear] [[Category:Sportswear brands]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 1887]] [[Category:Sporting goods manufacturers of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in St. Louis County, Missouri]] [[Category:Pearson plc]] [[Category:1887 establishments in Missouri]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/179.236.16.182|179.236.16.182]] ([[User talk:179.236.16.182|talk]]) to last revision by KolbertBot. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Infobox football club | clubname = Shabab Rafah | image = Shabab Rafah (logo).png | fullname = Shabab Rafah Sports Club | nickname = | founded = 1953 | ground = Rafah Municipal Stadium
[[Rafah]], [[Gaza Strip]] (''de jure'' [[State of Palestine|Palestine]]) | capacity = 5,000 | chrtitle = Head Coach | chairman = Jamal Al-Haouli | mgrtitle = | manager = | league = [[Gaza Strip League]] | season = 2015–16 | position = '''3rd''' place | current = | pattern_la1 = | pattern_b1 = | pattern_ra1 = | leftarm1 = | body1 = | rightarm1 = | shorts1 = | socks1 = }} '''Shabab Rafah Sports Club''' ({{lang-ar|نادي شباب رفح الرياضي}}) or simply '''Shabab Rafah''' is a [[Palestinian National Authority|Palestinian]] [[association football|football]] team from the city of [[Rafah]] that plays in the [[Gaza Strip League]]. ==History== The club was founded in 1953 under the name of '''Al-Shoaba Club'''. In 1960, it changed the name to '''Al-Oruba Club'''. In 1962, the Egyptian administration in the Gaza Strip founded a Youth Care Foundation and parained the club who changed the name to '''Nadi Markaz Reayat Al-Shabab''' (Youth Care Center Club).{{cite web |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesp/palesfound.html |title=Palestine - List of Foundation Dates |work=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] |publisher=Hassanin Mubarak |date=February 14, 2014 |accessdate= }} After the [[Six-Day War]] of 1967, the club's activities stopped until 1973, the year when some of the loyal club members worked for the reconstruction and the revival of the club under the new name of the '''Shabab Rafah Sports Club''' and it formed the first administrative body headed by '''Ali Mehdi'''. ==Achievements== *'''[[Gaza Strip League]]''' :Champions (2) : 2008–09, 2013–14 *'''Gaza Strip Cup''' :Winners (3) : 2002–03, 2005–12, 2012 *'''Gaza Strip Super Cup''' :Winners (2) : 2013, 2014 ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/palestine/shabab-rafah Team profile] - ''Soccerway.com'' [[Category:Football clubs in the State of Palestine]] [[Category:1953 establishments in All-Palestine (Gaza)]] {{Palestine-footyclub-stub}}
